I won't burden the Court with many quotes from the various cases which were in our brief, but with this Court, I'm sure, well aware of -- that we feel that all the State of Maryland has done is to set up the safeguards and as the Court of Appeals in its language said, Justice Henderson, “That this requirement to declare a belief in the existence of God on a part of a Notary Public or such a security of good conduct on the part of public officials that this requirement was not so unreasonable as to be invidious for the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, may I -- may I ask, is it clear in this case that -- that this man is an atheist as distinguished from a non-believer or such as an agnostic or -- or let us say, some other religion, is it fair in the record that -- that he is an atheist?

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: I believe in the petition, Mr. Justice, that if he filed for the mandamus, he sets forth in there that he is an atheist.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's enough if --

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: Or maybe not.
I -- certainly as counsel has -- has so characterized him and the --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, that's who I'd like to see it.
I'll look for it and (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Has your court then put any gloss on this as to -- to whether it would apply only to -- to atheist as distinguished from agnostics or -- or rather religious beliefs that did not necessarily recognize a Supreme Being?

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They treat them all the same so far as the -- the interpretation of the courts is concerned -- the courts are concerned.

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: As long as they won't take the -- an oath in the declaration of the belief in the existence --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: -- of God.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So you think this case here is not just as though he's an atheist, but as you -- as if he was anyone who wouldn't -- not for any reason to take the oath.

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: Our Court of Appeals used this language and said that they did not feel that the First Amendment of the United States Constitution was ever intended to embrace and encompass the ungodly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The what?

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: The ungodly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh, the ungodly.

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: To do what term?

turn.speaker: thomas_b_finan
turn.label: Mr. Thomas B. Finan
turn.text: He has -- just for the Maryland Court of Appeals, Judge Henderson and his language in the opinion on that case said that in his -- it's his interpretation that the First Amendment to the United States Constitution was never intended to encompass the ungodly.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Kaufman.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I think Your Honors last question as to the form of the proceedings is very important.
This case arose on a petition for mandamus to require the Clerk of the Circuit Court from Montgomery County to issue to the appellant here, his commission as a Notary Public.
The Clerk gave to the petitioner and appellant here, the necessary oath which she was to subscribe prior to the issuance of the commission.
The appellant refused and therefore the Clerk refused to issue the commission.
A writ of mandamus was then issued, petition for writ of mandamus was then issued and the State of Maryland through the Clerk, filed a demurrer.
The demurrer was sustained in the lower court and a final order was passed, dismissing the petition for writ of mandamus coming up on the demurrer.
No testimony was taken whatsoever and the record as you -- Honors can tell us a very short record.

However, I think the question as to what the religious belief or lack of religious belief of the appellant is -- was assumed through all the courts hated by oral argument or otherwise that he was an atheist.
Now --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) an allegation?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: There's no such allegation in the pleadings.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: But there could be no finding because we accepted the --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: -- we accepted the allegations of the petition in it by a reason of our demurrer.

Mr. Chief Justice and members of the Court, I feel obliged to advise the Court that we do have a practical situation here that I think counsel had entirely overlooked until this time and that the commission, for which Torcaso seeks, will of its own terms, expire the 1st day of May, 1961.
The commission of a Notary Public is for two years commencing on the first Monday of May, in each and every year, by the Maryland Constitution.
I point that out because I think it was overlooked and we think that the Court should be advised of that fact.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean nobody pleads this?
You -- the State has not --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Your Honor, we -- in preparing for our argument, this question came up and it was not briefed at prior to that.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Does it (Inaudible) from the time issued or from the time applied for?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: No, sir.
The commission is issued and the term expires on the 1st Monday of May, every two years.

In other words, you can't get a -- if you applied to be a Notary Public in between terms, your term -- but all -- all terms expire at the end of the 1st day of May -- 1st Monday of May in the alternate year.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is this another issue?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: No, sir.
This one has never issued.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are renewals automatic?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: No, sir.
They must be applied for --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know -- I know they must be applied for.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: -- certified --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is it formality?
The man has been a Notary for six years?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: If he does not reapply, he does not get his commission again.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If he can't reapply again (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I must be frank to say that the normal procedure is, is that the State Senator will send an application, blank to each Notary Public in the past and those who request them in the future, to fill out, return to him for certification, for forwarding to the Governor.
Now, I don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that an argument in political account?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that an argument of political account?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, I think that's good politics for any State Senator.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any limitation on the number of notaryships that can be --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Only political considerations with limit that, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what political consideration?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That's of the State Senator's feeling as to how many should be in his county

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It must come through the --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: It must be certified by the State Senator.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there anything in this Court that -- any (Inaudible) one way or the other that -- or renewal or renewed application will follow?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can a Unitarian be an officer in Maryland?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Can a Unitarian?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: To the best of my knowledge, he can't.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) had no constitutional right to be a Notary Public.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But didn't he have a constitutional right not to be excluded on religious grounds?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well if Your Honor please, he is not -- he has not qualified to hold any office in Maryland because he has refused to take an oath in the belief of the existence to God.
This is not -- we don't contend this is a religious oath as such, because a religious oath as such, indicates a belief in one sect as opposed to another.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, if this doesn't mean all that another person who does not in fact believes in God and he's willing to confess it can hold an office of profit or trust in Maryland.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: The question is whether or not that's permissible on the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That's -- I think that's what it results itself into.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Kaufman, you -- you mentioned the Everson case a few moments ago.

But, what would you do with -- with this language where it says in that case, “On the other hand, other language of the First Amendment commands that New Jersey cannot pamper its citizens in the free exercise of their own religion?

Consequently, it cannot exclude individual Catholics, Lutherans, Mohammedans, Baptist, Jews, Methodist, nonbelievers, Presbyterians or the members of any other faith, because of their faith or lack of it when receiving the benefits of public welfare legislation.
No person can be punished for entertaining or professing religious beliefs or disbeliefs for church attendants and non-attendants.”
Well, now --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: If I understand Your Honor's question correctly --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

That's one of the later cases that you -- that you have cited in your briefs concerning the religious character of our -- of our Government and I'm not disputing that we are a religious people or that our Government does contemplate a belief in -- in God, but -- but this language in Everson speaks of punishing a person by refusing him the -- the benefits of welfare and legislation, because he doesn't happen to conform and this says that he -- it cannot be done regardless of whether he believes or disbelieves.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That is correct, sir.
But it's a quite a different proposition when you're dealing with the qualifications for public office.
Now, we have other qualifications in the Maryland Constitution for public office and to be a Notary Public, there are residence requirements.
And we think that those are reasonable qualifications.
We're not saying that he is a -- non-entitled to welfare benefits or welfare legislation benefits.
We're saying he is not qualified to hold public office.

The people of Maryland speaking in their constitution feel that this is a reasonable requirement and unless there is some constitutional prohibition, we think that the Court should say that it is none and unreasonable qualification for public office.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But as one member of the Court asked if the Attorney General a few moments to ago, when you deprive a man of the right to hold public office, such as this or any other office in the State of Maryland, because of his religion for lack of it, are you not interfering with his liberty as an American citizen?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, you are to a certain degree, I agree restricting his liberty, but are you unconstitutionally restricting his liberty?
Does he have a constitutional guarantee to that?
We have many minor restrictions on liberty, but we say that they do not impinge upon any constitutional guarantee and that's what our contention is, here.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, unless you -- now -- now, what would you -- how would you claim or get along the language of the West Virginia (Inaudible) case, the Barnettee -- the Barnettee case, that one may not be compelled to utter what is not in his mind.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, I think if Your Honor please, there's no compulsion here.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: There's no compulsion in this case for Mr. Torcaso to be a Notary Public.
We're not compelling him to accept that political office.
He's accepting it because he wants it.
He's applied for it, but he's not qualified for it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And all they were doing -- mayor was to say that children were not qualified to be in the public schools, if they didn't take the oath.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: No, sir.
I -- I don't think so.
I think that that case, do it for the proposition that the parents of these children were compelled to send them there under criminal penalty in the event that they didn't send them to school.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: And this was a part of the school process.
I think the compulsion aspect is completely obliviated here because there is no compulsion to accept this political office.

The point here is as distinguished from the Barnette case, is that there, the children had to go to school under a paying of criminal sanction and penalty to the parents, if the children did not attend.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And they --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: There is no such compulsion here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- would not let them attend -- they wouldn't let them attend, if they didn't -- they didn't take the oath, isn't it right?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well that -- that was the criminal compulsion there that they had a penalty in the event that they did not comply with the proceedings in the schools of West Virginia.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If your state law said, no Protestant or Catholics, or no Jew either one, could not hold public office, would you say that was putting in a compulsion on him?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: If Your Honor please, I don't think that's a case of compulsion.
I think that would be unreasonable under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I understand unreasonable.
I don't know exactly what that means, but would that be compulsion?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: To hold public office, no sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.
Would that be compulsion?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: I think not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You think there'd be no compulsions put on him to belong to what the covered church was -- was decided with -- with any interest to Maryland to avoid possible trouble that this good citizen -- only citizen to this good church and hold a -- or is not?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: But that's the -- that's the point here.
We don't say Torcaso has to belong to church A or church B or church C, he can belong to any church, or not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you say he can't -- you say he must belong to one in order to hold office.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: He must -- he don't even have to belong --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But he has to believe in one?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: He has to believe in the existence of God that our --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But judges (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: -- our rights come from some higher being than just man itself.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The only question I was asking about compulsion.

Suppose it said, no man, who's an atheist, can hold this job with the public and this job to the State, this job to the Federal Government, this job somewhere else, or this job over here or this job job over here.
And finally, they got quite a number.
Would you say still say there's no compulsion on him?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well if Your Honor please, in my thinking, there's been no compulsion and there would be no compulsion.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Suppose he's just an agnostic and he said now, in all good (Inaudible) I just don't know for the -- and therefore, I refuse to say that I believe in God.
That man cannot hold office of trust for profit in Maryland?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That is correct, sir, if he refuses to meet the qualifying test.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that would be would it not, if he really didn't know and he was uncertain, wouldn't that be to make him say something that was not in his mind?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: I don't think so, sir.
He -- he's not required to say it.
If he doesn't know then he shouldn't say anything.
He's not required to say it.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But those who are willing to say can hold office for trust or profit (Inaudible) but those who are unwilling to say it because they're doubtful are denied to it or denied the right of one of the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you do with the statement about Justice Roberts, I believe it was in Cantwell, that belief is invaluable?
The biggest government, the most powerful government can't interfere with this.
But we're not trying to interfere with his belief.
He can believe as we said before in anything he desires to believe in, but the question is, if he does not believe in the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Because it's just a small job, the State had.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Or he can --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose it's a big job, suppose the government.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: He can -- he can hold any employment in the State as a ministerial officer, but he cannot hold a political office or office for profit, because the people of the State feel that that is a reasonable requirement as expressed in the Constitution.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think that people of Maryland have a right to use that judgment of what's reasonable to bar people from having office, because they do not believe in God?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, if Your Honor, I -- I must say that I think the people through the constitutional process, do have that right.
They have recognized in the very preamble to the Constitution, itself.
The Constitution of Maryland that they're -- all their rights under their -- the Maryland Government come from God.
The preamble to the Constitution of Maryland itself is based upon that assumption.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What does it say, Mr. Kaufman?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: It says, “We, the People of State of Maryland, grateful to Almighty God for our civil and religious liberty, and taking into our serious consideration the best means of establishing a good Constitution in the State and with a sure foundation -- for the sure foundation and more permanent security thereof, declare.”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you think they meant by grateful power, civil and religious liberty?[Laughter]

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, I think they meant grateful to our -- as far as religious liberty is concerned, they have freedom of -- to worship in any sect or cult that they desire.
Because just as this Court in the Davis versus Beason case, defined religion as the manner in which one fulfills his obligation to his maker.
This Court recognized that there is a Supreme Being.

Mr. Justice Hughes -- Mr. Chief Justice Hughes in speaking of it said, “One cannot speak of religious liberty, but proper appreciation of its essential and historical significance without assuming the existence of a belief in supreme allegiance to the will of God.”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you find anything in that to support your belief that Mr. Chief Justice Hughes supported a test oath, religious test oath?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, if Your Honor please, I can only quote from his language that the religious liberty and existence of a belief in a supreme allegiance to the will of God are essential one to the other.

And I might say, if Your Honor please, in the Davis versus Beason case, there was an oath in that case that had to be taken to the effect that you did not believe in polygamy or it did not belong to any organization that advocated polygamy in order to hold public office in the territory of Idaho.

And this Court said that that did not invade the religious liberty and the person involved because in our free society, persons who believe under the guise of religion and under the statement of religion and things that are inimicable to our society cannot hold public office.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that -- that was because polygamy was a -- a crime under -- under the law, isn't it?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: It was a -- it was crime under the territory law.
That's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: -- but this --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There's no -- nothing in -- in Maryland that makes this a crime, is it?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To not believe --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Not to believe and there's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: -- nothing that makes it a crime.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You concede you couldn't do that, don't you?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I wouldn't want to do it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you're saying is that if it is a legal doctrine, but we are religious people presumably, religious people can -- can take measures to sustain the presupposition of their society, that's what you're saying, isn't it?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Well, I -- you stated it not quite as I would, but I think that -- that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not saying I do [Laughter] what I said, but it -- it is not with that presupposition.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: We -- we must --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The Court does a lot of talk in -- in cases and opinion to this Court which have to be looked at (Inaudible) that hard, if you were to take it literally, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Sir, I -- I think that you, of course, have to see what the case holds and that -- then fit the language to the holding of the case, but before, and I'm trying to say here is, it is not unreasonable for -- because of this requirement -- because our whole form of Government is based upon this presupposition.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what opinions say.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: Opinions say in their --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Take that at --

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: -- in their flat holdings, if Your Honor please, in the day of this Beason case was a flat holding.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Kaufman, in view of the fact that mootness was raised for the first time, would you mind giving us a -- a memorandum before Friday with your views concerning mootness?

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: I'll do it -- even before then, if Your Honors --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, just to show that you can, but so we'll have it by -- by Friday and I'll ask counsel.
They'll decide to do the same thing, if they will.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Before Friday.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, before Friday.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: I'll be glad to do that, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: In light of the fact that -- that we are going to submit a memorandum, I won't discuss the question of the possible mootness before the Court.

To allay the fears of the Attorney General as to whether the restriction on married ceremonies in Maryland might be tested which requires religious ceremonies and say that Mr. Torcaso along with his wife and three children, is not going to be the one to test that particular provision.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I gather he was married by a minister (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: I'm not sure whether he's married in Maryland.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He might have been married in New York.

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: That's possible.[Laughs]

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's not a religous (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: joseph_s_kaufman
turn.label: Mr. Joseph S. Kaufman
turn.text: As far as this, “So help me God,” as it patched to oath, we covered this in our brief.
There are a wide span of oaths, some of which are set out in -- in law which have the words, “So help me God”, some did not.
This doesn't affect whether it's an oath or not.
As a matter of fact, in the provision of the Maryland code itself, which sets out the oath of office on page 4 of the transcript of record, they don't have the words, “So help me God” there.
It's on top of page 4 and they set this out completely.
Now, as far as Hamilton versus University of California, there you had a problem in which the -- you had before the Court the question of the -- the right of a country to protect itself.

The war power of the State versus the religious beliefs of individuals and the Court has held that the right to be a conscientious objector is a matter of grace and that was the issue that was before the Court in University of California, the Hamilton case in which ROTC was considered a part of self-preservation of -- of the State.

Now, as far as the coercion aspect of this, may I refer the Court to the Cummings case in which -- Cummings versus Missouri, 18 L.Ed 356 in which at some length, they traced the history of religious test oaths, they traced the question, the denial of public office, denial of all sorts of benefits is a form of compulsion, is a form of penalty, they make the flat statement "disqualification from office maybe punishment" and they cite the history of -- of test oaths in England and France.
Other examples would be denial of a tax exemption even more of a privilege if you want to put it on a privilege basis than the -- a public office.
In Speiser versus Randall, you held that denial of a privilege there can infringe on constitutional rights.

In the Dowd case, it was -- which -- which covered political leaders that it was -- the Court said that denying office of a political leader will infringe, but they determine whether or not, that it's reasonable under the -- under the conditions that existed.
I listened.
I did not hear the opposing counsel say why this was reasonable.
They -- they kept emphasizing this is a reasonable qualification for office and I fail to hear one word as to why this was a reason for qualification.
What this provision has to do with ensuring that an individual is going to do the job is going to perform the task of a Notary Public or any other public office.
There was no word made in their argument covering why it was a reasonable qualification.
In conclusion, I'd like to say that this case was anachronism of the 20th century.
Many of the arguments that were made here were made in 18th and 19th century.
And I urge the Court that this provision be sent back to the 18th and 19th century where -- with some emotion and fervor people argued about religious test oaths of this kind.
Such an oath as this does not belong in the 20th century.
